Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Novel Electron-Nuclear Dual Resonance Instrument with Arbitrary Microwave Pulse Shaping to Advance the Structure and Dynamics Study of Biological Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
An arbitrary pulse shaping module at X-band (10 GHz) frequencies will be integrated into an EPR spectrometer that will lead to unprecedented and fundamentally important advances, including dramatic enhancement of excitation bandwidths, reduction of the prohibitively long dead times of current pulsed EPR instruments, and the experimental realization of Fourier Transform EPR with high spectral resolution. The implementation of arbitrarily shaped microwave pulses will also enable the next generation of quantitative and time-resolved Overhauser DNP spectroscopy to probe the dynamics of the otherwise invisible, loosely bound hydration water around proteins with site specificity. The proposed development will capitalize on state of the art integrated circuit components to generate X-band waveforms, whose amplitude and phase can be specified on the fly with sub-ns resolution. This control, coupled with the unsurpassed, built-in flexibility of a commercial pulsed EPR spectrometer will offer an instrument with a wide range of qualities and capabilities novel to pulsed EPR and DNP.

State of the art EPR spectrometers do not yet offer the ability to shape individual pulses, as has routinely been done in modern NMR and MRI experiments for 25 years. This work proposes, for the first time, to implement arbitrarily shaped pulses for EPR experiments at the most commonly used X-band frequencies. This development has the potential to dramatically advance the accuracy, time resolution, and spectral resolution of current pulsed EPR and DNP experiments, allowing them to measure structural parameters, interactions, and dynamics of complex and large biological systems that are inaccessible to other methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcome is the successful development and building of a stand-alone electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer for X-band (8-12 GHz) operation with full arbitrary waveform generation (AWG) control at high microwave power (1 kWatt) by relying on a 1 GHz digital-to-analogue (DAC) board with a very high dynamic range (14 bit) [1], as well as the extension of AWG-EPR from X-band to G-band (~200 GHz) for versatile pulsed EPR operation at high magnetic fields (see Figure) [2]. Especially as stand-alone home built units, these represent state of the art developments that have the potential to dramatically enhance the performance and scope of pulsed EPR experimentation in fundamental ways. The intellectual merit is reflected in the demonstration that EPR hardware limitations and imperfections can be compensated for by software control when fully digital AWG is a routine capability. These include the compensation of the microwave cavity transfer function by AWG shaping of the input pulses [1], or the active cancellation of cavity ring-down for deadtime-free detection of the EPR signal by concurrent irradiation during signal detection with shaped pulses that are precisely inverse of the unwanted cavity ringdown artefact [3]. The broader impact is that our study has debuted a general and readily available EPR instrument platform that will broadly impact the scope of EPR research in the future, as well as other research fields, including quantum information processing and beyond, as well as enhance the commercialization opportunity of similar instrumentation.

 

[1] DAC-board based X-band EPR Spectrometer with Arbitrary Waveform Control, T. Kaufmann, T.J. Keller, J.M. Franck, R.P. Barnes, S.J. Glaser, J.M. Martinis, S. Han, J. Magn. Reson. 235 (2013) 95-108. PMCID: PMC3863685.

[2] A versatile and modular quasi optics-based 200 GHz dual dynamic nuclear polarization and electron paramagnetic resonance instrument, T.A. Siaw, A. Leavesley, A. Lund, I. Kaminker, S. Han, J. Magn. Reson. 264 (2016) 131-153. PMCID: ?PMC4770585

[3] Active Cancellation - A Means to Zero Dead-Time Pulse EPR, J. Franck, R. Barnes, T. Keller, T. Kaufmann, S. Han, J. Magn. Reson., 261 (2015) 199-204. PMCID: PMC4688155
